question.text: Select the statement that correctly relates to biogas and sewage treatment process.

options.text: Activated sludge sediment in settlement tanks of the sewage treatment plant is a rich source of aerobic bacteria.
Biogas is produced by the activity of aerobic bacteria on animal waste.
Methanobacterium is an aerobic bacterium found in rumen of cattle's.
Biogas, commonly called gobar gas is pure methane.

solution.text: Once the BOD of sewage or wastewater is reduced significantly, the effluent is then passed into a settling tank where the bacterial ‘flocs’ are allowed to sediment. This sediment is called activated sludge. A small part of the activated sludge is pumped back into the aeration tank to serve as the inoculum. This inoculum serves as a rich source of aerobic bacteria. The remaining major part of the sludge is pumped into large tanks called anaerobic sludge digesters. Here, other kinds of bacteria, which grow anaerobically, digest the bacteria and the fungi in the sludge. During this digestion, bacteria produce a mixture of gases such as methane, hydrogen sulphide and carbon dioxide. These gases form biogas and can be used as source of energy as it is inflammable.
